You got this one?
I got this one, yeah.

10.36.text:
Digital art is just art made
in a digital age.

24.38.text:
We've been looking very much
at the kind of materiality of data,

28.34.text: and what might mean for us as artists.

34.30.text:
Digital art has been around
since the 1950s in a sense,

38.25.text:
but not many museums and galleries
had really been focusing on it

43.77.text:
But I think in the last 10 years
that's really changed.

46.84.text:
And many venues around the world
are really having a serious look

49.85.text:
at this area and the artists
who are working in it.

54.33.text:
There have been recent shows
at the V&A, the Tate,

57.38.text:
and now the big exhibition
at the Barbican.

59.48.text: And I think there'll be many more to come.

64.31.text:
I was the curator of Digital Revolution,
which was an exhibition which took place

67.63.text: at the Barbican Center in summer 2014.

70.75.text:
The exhibition looked broadly
at digital creativities.

73.88.text:
So we're looking at the areas of arts,
design, film, music and video games.

78.58.text:
So there was a kind of broad overview
of that subject, but also with a sense

87.19.text:
One of the really significant works
in the exhibition is the Pinocchio Lamp.

92.12.text:
It's learning from you. It has a camera
built into him that can recognise

95.64.text:
gesture and facial expression using
Arduino and camera-based technology.

101.96.text:
On one level, it's a design item,
but I think it's sort of indicating

106.80.text:
that objects can have real character and
can engage us in new and exciting ways.

111.64.text: And for me that's what makes it art.

115.20.text: Another key highlight of the exhibition was

117.49.text: Chris Milk's Treachery of the Sanctuary

119.60.text:
which is this enormous
three screen narrative work,

123.29.text: using connect camera based technology, which allowed visitors to engage

140.86.text:
15 Folds is a digital art gallery.
Every month we pick a theme,

144.81.text: and we invite 15 artists to interpret the theme in form of a gif.

149.80.text: When we first started the project we would go out and approach artists,

153.10.text: people who's work we found online that we really liked,

155.54.text: we wanted to interact with, and that's something that

157.76.text: we definitely still do, but increasingly we have people approach us.

161.77.text: People literally all over the world are making work like this.

165.29.text: And we're one of the very few online dedicated spaces to gif art,

169.59.text: so it feels really amazing to give people's creativity a home

183.60.text:
I guess really we're artists,
and data is our material.

187.46.text: If you go to our website and look at the work we make,

190.25.text:
you know, it's very easy to describe us
as digital artists.

193.76.text:
But as far as we are concerned
we're just artists that work

196.76.text:
within the contemporary art context.
And we really come out

199.88.text: of all of the kinds of concerns that we share with other artists

203.48.text: that might be working sculpturally, or working with paint,

205.99.text: or any kind of material in fact.

208.52.text:
We were thinking,
"Well, if data is our material,

210.93.text:
can we draw with it?"
And so this is us trying to draw

218.00.text: Decorative news feed is an automatic drawing.

221.04.text:
So it's a kind of endless animation
that uses syndicated news headlines

225.69.text: the RSS feeds, and then takes a news feeds at random

229.51.text: and displays it on a screen according to a set of rules.

233.06.text: So it's an instruction based artwork.

236.13.text: Of course news presents itself as a form of truth.

239.41.text: And if we just cross two or three headlines together,

242.39.text: perhaps it draws your attention to how what is purported to be fact

252.54.text:
There's some great new platforms
that have developed to showcase this work.

256.30.text: One of my favourites is "The Creators Project,"

258.59.text: which is collaboration between Intel and Vice, which is a great resource

262.01.text: for the kind of new digital work across the areas

264.44.text: of contemporary art, film, and music.

267.66.text:
A new platform that's been around
I think for a few months now is "The Space"

272.07.text:
which is this fantastic platform
for new commissions in the digital domain,

276.46.text: and the fantastic space for artists to showcase their latest work,

279.73.text: which is a free and very accessible web-based platform.

283.65.text:
There are huge opportunities
for young artists, designers, filmmakers,

287.57.text: to kinda get involved in this area.

290.07.text:
If you wanna get involved, I think,
you know, blog culture is so strong

293.41.text:
at the moment. You can set up
your own blog in seconds

296.85.text:
and start posting your own work,
and, you know, you gain followers

300.59.text:
and people see your work and...
It's also taking an interest

303.45.text:
in other people's work and re-blogging
and building this sense of community,

308.33.text: which I think is really important.

311.70.text:
You don't have to be alone anymore.
And I think that whole notion

314.92.text:
of a struggling kind of artist
in the studio kind of waiting

318.33.text:
for the next opportunity
in the galleries is no more.

321.62.text:
You can really be out there practicing
amongst a very wide communities

325.29.text:
and getting an instant response, which is
why digital is so exciting I think.
